Package org.protune.net

Key concepts Package org.protune.net provides a number of classes taking care of the issues related with the communication among nodes of a network.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Message In order to grant that communication among nodes actually takes place, it is required that each node is able to understand the information it receives, which means that the nodes need to share the same information representation.
NegotiationMessage Interface NegotiationMessage represents a generic message exchanged between two Peers during a negotiation.
NegotiationResult Interface NegotiationResult represents the generic result of a negotiation.
Peer The interface Peer represents a generic node of a Peer to Peer network.
Pointer In order to grant that communication among nodes actually takes place, it is required that the information sent by one node is received by the other one, which means that each node needs to have a reference (pointer) to the location of the other one.
 

Class Summary
AddressPortPointer Simple implementation of the Pointer interface, suitable for the cases in which a pair (address, port) as itself identifies an instance of a service.
DispatcherMessage A DispatcherPeer is able to handle many negotiations concurrently.
DispatcherPeer When a service is provided by a node and made available to the outer world throught the Internet, most likely a number of clients will request the service concurrently.
DispatcherPointer A DispatcherPeer is able to handle many negotiations concurrently.
DispatcherStartNegotiationMessage Classes ServiceRequestMessage, ServiceAvailableMessage, ServiceNotAvailableMessage and DispatcherStartNegotiationMessage were developed in order to support negotiations with a DispatcherPeer.
EndNegotiationMessage In the Protune system we are mostly interested in negotiations among (pairs of) peers.
OngoingNegotiationMessage In the Protune system we are mostly interested in negotiations among (pairs of) peers.
Service A Service object represents a service provided on some node of the network, whose result should be sent back to the client asking for it.
ServiceAvailableMessage Classes ServiceRequestMessage, ServiceAvailableMessage, ServiceNotAvailableMessage and DispatcherStartNegotiationMessage were developed in order to support negotiations with a DispatcherPeer.
ServiceNotAvailableMessage Classes ServiceRequestMessage, ServiceAvailableMessage, ServiceNotAvailableMessage and DispatcherStartNegotiationMessage were developed in order to support negotiations with a DispatcherPeer.
ServiceRequestMessage Classes ServiceRequestMessage, ServiceAvailableMessage, ServiceNotAvailableMessage and DispatcherStartNegotiationMessage were developed in order to support negotiations with a DispatcherPeer.
StartNegotiationMessage In the Protune system we are mostly interested in negotiations among (pairs of) peers.
SuccessfulNegotiationResult A SuccessfulNegotiationResult object represents a successful result of a negotiation and should be used to communicate that the outcome of the negotiation was successful.
UnsuccessfulNegotiationResult An UnsuccessfulNegotiationResult object represents an unsuccessful result of a negotiation and should be used to communicate that the outcome of the negotiation was unsuccessful.
 

Exception Summary
WrongMessageTypeException Exception to be sent when some entity during a negotiation realises that the message it is working on does not belong to the expected type.
 

Package org.protune.net Description

Key concepts

Package org.protune.net provides a number of classes taking care of the issues related with the communication among nodes of a network. A generic node of a Peer to Peer network is represented by the interface Peer.
This package tries to hide the further complexity requested by the communication among nodes of a network by providing facilities which should let the programmer to focus on the application. The application logic is represented by the (abstract) class Service which should be extended by the programmer by incapsulating the application logic in a subclass of it.

The network infrastructure

In order to grant that communication among nodes actually takes place, it is required that

  • the information sent by one node is received by the other one
  • each node is able to understand the information it receives

which means that

  • each node needs to have a reference (pointer) to the location of the other one
  • the nodes need to share the same information representation

In order to ensure that the previously mentioned requirements are satisfied, package org.protune.net provides the interfaces Pointer and Message.

  • The first one represents the abstraction of a reference to another node. A concrete implementation can simply exploit socket (as the current one in the Protune system) or whatever more complex means (RPC, RMI, Web Services ...), as long as the method Pointer.sendMessage(Message) is provided, ensuring that the information which should be received by the other node is actually sent.
  • The second one represents the common format of the information the two nodes exchange. Different applications can implement the interface in different ways.

The Protune system

In the Protune system we are mostly interested in negotiations among (pairs of) peers. A negotiation starts, goes on and finishes.

  • In the first part the handshaking takes place
  • In the second part the out-and-out negotiation takes place
  • In the third part the negotiation finishes and the overall result of the negotiation is provided

According to the various steps of the negotiation, package org.protune.net provides the classes StartNegotiationMessage, OngoingNegotiationMessage and EndNegotiationMessage, which are all implementation of the interface NegotiationMessage. The concept of "negotiation result" is provided by the interface NegotiationResult; so far this interface is implemented by the classes SuccessfulNegotiationResult and UnsuccessfulNegotiationResult. Exensions are possible in the future.
